text: Patient: So, you’re, you’re trying to drive the level, the level down so when the surge happens, it doesn’t peak, or it peaks as low as it - Family Member: Okay. Patient: Yay. You know, this is the opportunity for you to ask me questions and see if there is any reason that you want to abort, uh, or say this is the right way to go. Uh, and, then, I’ll get your medicines written and plan for your hormone shot in two weeks. And, then, we can leave it a little bit up in the air between T_, myself, as to what, uh day per our calendar when you wanna just say, “Okay, this is…” Patient: Well, well, well, we’ll work within that, that four-week window of the month. Doctor: Yeah, and if he had a little bit more flexibility, just again, if we started then, and it ends up on Christmas and the holidays. Healthcare Professional: Yeah, Doctor: Yeah. Patient: From when I talk to people, first dose of chemo, most of the guys that I talk to, not a huge impact effect with nausea or, or anything. Um, it was the second or third that they really started to feel um -

text: Patient: Well okay so you’re talking three different options. Doctor: Yeah basically. Patient: Which one, which one I guess was your recommendation? Doctor: What I was going to propose is that we do things in parallel. Okay? I was going to sort of leave the chemotherapy as a last possible option only because you have it available at any time. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: You know we can go to it if none of these work or even after they work and then stop working after sometime. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. And who knows what we may have by then too. If you don’t need it at all at that time. The, the I was going to sugg-propose that we do the prescreening and the blood test in anticipation of doing that testing for your blood today. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And that way we have at least that cooking… Family Member: Check the markers and? Doctor: Right. If the markers are positive, I think you should go on the Niraparib, the PARP inhibitor - the targeted treatment…

text: Patient: That, that’s, okay. Doctor: Uh, the, uh, the idea of those drugs. It depends on which of the drugs. There’s a bunch of different HIV drugs. I can’t remember which one you mentioned. text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: We sort of made that be like uh a line in the sand so to speak, so- Patient: What about the PSMA, uh? Doctor: So that was going to be the next thing. Patient: Oh. Okay. Doctor: Uh, we, there’s going to be a trial that’s a multi-centered trial that coming on-line, but it’s going to be a while. Uh, right now I think the trial is still ongoing at Cornell. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And there’s actually a group that would get you back to California. There’s a group at UCLA (laughs) Patient: And how does, what’s the effect of that when you get treated? I mean what is, what’s different about that? Would that, would that go after the growth in the lymph nodes? Doctor: Yes. So PSMA is a thing that’s on the surface of crossing cancer cells. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And it’s an enzyme, which means uh we’re not really sure what it does but we are, we’re able to block its function with a with a small drug. text: Family Member: everyone gets chemo. Which is great for me, you’re like wow, I guess it’s great for you but you know we all have mixed feelings a little bit. I get that. Patient: Right. Doctor: The second study is chemotherapy plus an immunotherapy versus chemotherapy. So, docetaxel plus immunotherapy versus docetaxel. So, you know, either one of those is doable. Again, if you had stuff outside of bone that’s probably what we should do. Hi, oh, for the opioids, Okay, for your pain, yeah. So, then the other part is what if you’re just bone. So, let’s say we do this and you’re just in your bones, no lymph nodes, liver, nothing, it’s clean then I think we should consider radium or Xofigo. Family Member: Together with the docetaxel? Doctor: No, just radium. So, there it’s um to combine with anything else is not standard of care and we don’t have our trial up yet with radium plus something. But, at this moment standard of care is just monthly radium for six months and that improves your survival span. So does chemotherapy but radium you can only give if it’s just in bone. So, if you have it like in the liver or whatever kind of like when we first started Patient: Um hum. Doctor: it was like oh, no you kind of had these bits and pieces, Patient: Right. Doctor: one, your insurance won’t approve it and number two it’s the wrong treatment. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But, if that’s sort of gone and nowhere to be found on this CAT scan then I think radium is it. Now, radium does two things. One is that it helps you live longer but also helps with pain so those people who are, you know, whether you’re taking a Tylenol over-the-counter or you’re taking actual narcotics that should improve. Patient: Okay.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
